reviewText: I just watched this movie on t.v. here in the UK and I think we must have seen an edited version, as I do not recall hearing the "F" word. It was entertaining enough and the two girls are lovely, but I am just wondering about what constitutes a "family" movie these days if this sort of language and a couple of suggestive scenes can qualify!!

reviewText: Christmas in Boston is about a young woman named Gina (Marla Sokoloff).  Gina is a journalist at  a Boston newspaper and a guy named Seth (Patrick J. Adams) is a toy inventor. Seth lives in Denver.  Gina and Seth have known each other since 6th grade school.  Gina and Seth have been pen pals since 6th grade. Now Gina and Seth are all grown up.  Gina and Seth have been been writing for 13 years but they have never met.  Seth has to go to a toy convention  in Boston.  Gina has to write about the toy convention.  Both Gina and Seth did not send pictures of the of themselves.  Gina and Seth used their better looking best friends, Ellen (Lindy Booth) and Matt (Jonathan Cherry).  Find out what happens  to Ellen and Matt.  Watch this movie so you can see if the real Gina and Seth ever met each other.  It is a real good movie! A perfect love story!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I watched this movie last night, and I thought it was one of the best christmas movies I've ever seen (and I've watched a lot).  The characters Seth and Gina (the real Seth and Gina) are utterly adorable.  Who wouldn't love the sweet and shy Seth?  His cluelessness regarding women was so endearing.  The way he looks at Gina when he realizes she's the woman he's been writing too all these years melted my heart.  Meanwhile the fake Seth and Gina are so hilirious.  I couldn't stop laughing at their misunderstandings - especially regarding her dog and his father.  I totally agree about this not being suitable for young children because there are some heavy make out scenes even though there is no nudity or bad language.  There is also an inappropriate version of "The Twelve Days of Christmas" song which is funny for adults, but not children.  I recommend this movie for ages 13 and up, depending on the maturity of the children.  I always watch movies first before letting my daughter view them, and I decide for myself if they're suitable.  My daughter is 9, so I will definitely be waiting a few years before letting her see this movie.  As for myself - I totally loved it, and recommend it to any die hard romantics out there.  I'll be watching this every christmas from now on.
summary: Adored it from beginning to end

reviewText: Two young children begin a pen-pal relationship while in sixth grade. The film starts when they are both young adults and his job takes him to Boston, where she lives and works. To this point, they have corresponded only by written word, but they decide that given the proximity, they should meet. At this point, the first implausibility arises. Each of them has been lying to the other, having sent photographs of friends rather than of themselves. So in planning the meeting, each convinces the friend whose photograph was used to go to the meeting instead. Thus, the supposed meeting of two long-time friends actually involves neither of them.Oddly, this first meeting offers, I think, the funniest moments of the film as the two stand-ins try to remember all the facts they have tried to memorize. For instance, he offers condolences to her on the loss of her dog. She, hearing the name and not connecting it with a dog, thinks that the loss must be an ex-boyfriend and notes that, truthfully, he was a lousy kisser. There are a couple of misunderstandings like this that are fairly humorous, albeit in a contrived way.At least one other reviewer has questioned the appropriateness of this film for family members. There is rather a lot of kissing, including one scene involving chocolate syrup that probably would make parents uncomfortable explaining to a pre-teen. So I think that reviewer's concern is appropriate.The biggest problem, at least to me, though, is the lack of real emotion and the contrivances in this film. At no time did I ever believe in either of the main characters or the resolution. For much better films dealing with epistolary relationships, I recommend84 Charing Cross RoadandJapanese Wife. For a better Christmas film dealing with new relationships, I recommendThe Christmas Wife(which is better for adults not because of objectionable material but because of its maturity) or evenMiracle on 34th Street.
summary: Very little plausibility or Christmas spirit

reviewText: Gina and Seth have been pen pals for 13 years and now at Christmatime will have the chance to meet for the first time. The onthly hitch is that both have used their best friends pictures to send to each other and now will let their friends meet. Will they be able to recognize each other from what they know about each other?
